source.name: General US recycling best practices
source.notes: Conservative baseline guidance. Check your local municipality for specific rules.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse the bottle
Replace the cap
Place in recycling bin
notes: Most curbside programs accept #1 (PET) and #2 (HDPE) plastics
commonMistakes: Don't crush bottles if your program uses optical sorting
Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Plastic containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove any film lids
Place in recycling bin
notes: Check the number on the bottom — #1, #2, and #5 are most commonly accepted
commonMistakes: Black plastic is often not recyclable
Film lids are usually trash

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT place in curbside recycling
Many grocery stores have drop-off bins for plastic bag recycling
If no drop-off is available, place in trash
notes: Plastic bags jam recycling machinery and are the #1 contaminant
commonMistakes: Never bag your recyclables in plastic bags
Don't put plastic wrap or film in curbside recycling

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
No need to crush (unless your program requires it)
Place in recycling bin
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable and one of the most valuable recyclables
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue
Aluminum foil is often accepted too — check locally

materials.name: Steel / tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place in recycling bin
notes: Use a magnet to test — steel cans are magnetic, aluminum is not
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove metal lids (recycle separately)
Place in recycling bin
notes: Some programs separate glass by color; check locally
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and trash it
Window glass, mirrors, and ceramics are NOT recyclable in curbside bins

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Break down and flatten boxes
Remove tape and packing materials if possible
Place in recycling bin
notes: Cardboard is one of the most successfully recycled materials
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cardboard soaked with grease (e.g., pizza boxes with oil stains)
Remove styrofoam and plastic inserts

materials.name: Newspaper
instructions: Place directly in recycling bin
No need to remove staples
notes: One of the oldest and most commonly recycled materials
commonMistakes: Don't include newspaper that's been used as packing material with food grease

materials.name: Paper
instructions: Place in recycling bin
Shredded paper should be placed in a paper bag first
notes: Most clean, dry paper is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues (those are compost/trash)
Don't include wax-coated paper

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Remove any leftover food
If the box is heavily greased on the bottom, tear off the greasy part and trash it
Recycle the clean top portion
notes: Many modern recycling programs now accept lightly soiled pizza boxes
commonMistakes: Don't include the wax paper liner
A few grease spots are usually OK — a soaking box is not

materials.name: Styrofoam
instructions: Place in trash
Some areas have specialized Styrofoam drop-off locations
notes: Expanded polystyrene (EPS) is not accepted in most curbside programs
commonMistakes: Don't put Styrofoam in recycling — it contaminates the stream
Packing peanuts can sometimes be returned to shipping stores

materials.name: Fruit / fruit scraps
instructions: Compost bin if your area has composting
Home composting works great for fruit scraps
If no composting available, place in trash
Never put in recycling
notes: Fruit is one of the best items for composting — it breaks down quickly
Citrus peels are fine in municipal composting but may slow home composting
commonMistakes: Don't put fruit in recycling
Don't throw fruit on the ground outdoors — it attracts pests

materials.name: Vegetables / vegetable scraps
instructions: Compost bin if available
Great for home composting
If no composting, place in trash
Never put in recycling
notes: All vegetables and vegetable scraps are compostable
Onion and garlic are fine in municipal composting
commonMistakes: Don't put vegetables in recycling

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in trash — most curbside composting does NOT accept meat
Wrap in newspaper or a bag to contain odor
Put out on collection day to avoid attracting animals
notes: Meat attracts pests and creates odor in compost bins
Some industrial composting facilities accept meat — check locally
Never pour meat grease down the drain
commonMistakes: Don't put in home compost bins — it attracts rats and creates odor
Don't put in recycling
Don't pour grease down the drain

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place in trash — most composting programs don't accept dairy
Pour expired milk down the drain (small amounts are fine)
Container goes in recycling after rinsing
notes: The dairy product itself goes in trash, but the container may be recyclable
Yogurt cups (#5 plastic) are recyclable after rinsing
commonMistakes: Don't compost dairy in home bins — it attracts pests
Don't forget to recycle the container separately

materials.name: Bread and grains
instructions: Compost if available — bread and grains break down well
If no composting, place in trash
Stale bread can also be left out for birds (in appropriate areas)
notes: Bread composts quickly but may attract pests in open bins
Cooked pasta and rice are compostable too
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
In home compost, bury bread under other material to avoid attracting pests

materials.name: Eggs / eggshells
instructions: Eggshells: crush and add to compost — they add calcium
Raw or cooked eggs: compost if available, otherwise trash
Never put in recycling
notes: Eggshells are excellent for compost and garden soil
Rinsing eggshells before composting reduces odor
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Crush eggshells before composting for faster breakdown

materials.name: Coffee grounds / tea bags
instructions: Coffee grounds and paper filters: compost
Tea bags: compost if they're paper (remove the staple)
If no composting, place in trash
notes: Coffee grounds are excellent for compost — they add nitrogen
Some tea bags contain plastic mesh — those go in trash
commonMistakes: Check that tea bags are paper, not plastic mesh
Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Cooked food / leftovers
instructions: Compost bin if your program accepts cooked food
Many curbside programs accept all food waste including cooked food
If no composting, place in trash
Scrape into compost/trash — don't put the plate in
notes: Check if your local program accepts cooked food — many do
Wrap in newspaper to reduce odor if trashing
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
The container/plate is separate from the food — dispose of each correctly

materials.name: Snacks and candy
instructions: The food itself: compost if available, otherwise trash
The wrapper/packaging: trash (see candy wrapper / chip bag entries)
Separate the food from its packaging
notes: The snack food is organic and compostable, but the wrapper almost never is
Gum is trash — it doesn't break down
commonMistakes: Don't put wrappers in compost — only the food
Chewing gum goes in trash, not compost

materials.name: Condiments and sauces
instructions: The sauce/condiment itself: compost or trash
Squeeze packets: trash (mixed materials)
Glass bottles: rinse and recycle
Plastic bottles: rinse and recycle
notes: Separate the container from the contents — they have different disposal paths
commonMistakes: Don't recycle bottles with sauce still in them — rinse first
Squeeze packets are trash, not recycling

materials.name: Beverages / drinks
instructions: Pour leftover liquid down the drain — small amounts are fine
The container goes in recycling (can, bottle, or carton)
Don't pour sugary drinks on the ground outside
notes: The liquid itself is fine to drain — focus on recycling the container
commonMistakes: Don't recycle containers with liquid still in them — empty first
Don't pour large amounts of milk or juice outside — use the drain

materials.name: Food waste (general)
instructions: If your area has curbside composting, place in compost bin
Otherwise, consider home composting
If neither is available, place in trash
notes: Food waste in landfills generates methane, a potent greenhouse gas
When in doubt about a specific food, it's almost certainly compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in recycling
Meat and dairy may not be accepted in all composting programs

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in yard waste bin if available
Many municipalities offer seasonal yard waste pickup
Can also be home composted
notes: Check local rules — some areas ban yard waste from trash
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags unless specified
Don't include treated wood or invasive plants

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Never place in regular trash or recycling
Take to a battery recycling drop-off (many hardware stores accept them)
Tape the terminals of lithium batteries before disposal
notes: Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks and recycling facilities
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in the trash
Don't put them in curbside recycling

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to an e-waste recycling center
Many retailers (Best Buy, Staples) offer free e-waste drop-off
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: It's illegal to put e-waste in the trash in many states
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in curbside recycling
Don't throw in trash — contains toxic materials

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent bulbs contain mercury — take to a hazardous waste drop-off
LED bulbs can go to e-waste recycling
Incandescent bulbs go in the trash (wrap to prevent breakage)
notes: Home Depot and Lowe's accept CFL bulbs for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in regular trash
Don't break them — mercury vapor is hazardous

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Latex paint: dry it out with kitty litter or sawdust, then trash the solidified paint
Oil-based paint: take to a hazardous waste facility
Never pour paint down the drain
notes: Many communities have paint recycling programs or swap events
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain or into storm drains
Empty dry paint cans can often be recycled as metal

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to an auto parts store or hazardous waste facility
Never pour down drains or on the ground
notes: Most auto parts stores accept used motor oil for free
commonMistakes: Don't mix motor oil with other fluids
Don't pour into storm drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a pharmacy drug take-back program
Many police stations have drop-off boxes
If no drop-off available: mix with coffee grounds or kitty litter, seal in a container, and trash
notes: DEA National Prescription Drug Take Back Day happens twice a year
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications down the toilet (unless specifically instructed)
Don't throw in regular trash without rendering unusable

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate wearable clothing to thrift stores
Place unwearable textiles in textile recycling bins
Some retailers accept old clothing (H&M, North Face)
notes: Textiles in landfills take decades to decompose
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in curbside recycling
Wet or moldy clothing should be trashed

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off food residue
Ball up into a fist-sized ball for easier processing
Place in recycling bin
notes: Many programs accept clean aluminum foil
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil contaminated with food
Foil-lined chip bags are NOT recyclable

materials.name: Paper towels and napkins
instructions: If you have composting: add to compost bin
Otherwise: place in trash
Never place in recycling
notes: Paper towels cannot be recycled because the fibers are too short
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Paper towels used with chemicals should go in trash, not compost

materials.name: Milk / juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if it has one
Place in recycling bin
notes: Most curbside programs now accept cartons — check locally
commonMistakes: Don't flatten cartons — 3D shape helps sorting machines identify them

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Do NOT puncture
Remove plastic cap and recycle separately
Place empty can in recycling bin
notes: Non-empty aerosols may be considered hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized or has product remaining
Never puncture aerosol cans

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Let cool completely
Pour into a sealed non-recyclable container
Place sealed container in trash
Some areas have cooking oil recycling programs
notes: Never pour oil or grease down the drain — it causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour down the sink
Don't pour into storm drains

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Wrap used diapers tightly
Place in trash
notes: Diapers are not recyclable or compostable in most municipal programs
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Some specialty services offer diaper composting — check locally

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Most paper coffee cups are NOT recyclable due to plastic lining
Place in trash
Plastic lids are often recyclable — check locally
notes: Consider using a reusable cup to reduce waste
commonMistakes: Don't put lined paper cups in recycling
The plastic lid and paper sleeve may be recyclable separately

materials.name: Wine corks
instructions: Natural cork: compost or recycle at specialty programs
Synthetic cork: place in trash
Whole Foods and some wine shops accept corks for recycling
notes: Natural cork is biodegradable
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a tire retailer or auto shop
Many municipalities offer tire collection events
Never dump illegally
notes: Most tire retailers are required to accept old tires when you buy new ones
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside trash
Don't dump in nature

materials.name: Needles / sharps
instructions: Place in an FDA-cleared sharps container
When full, take to a designated drop-off or mail-back program
Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
notes: Improper disposal puts sanitation workers at risk
commonMistakes: Never put in recycling
Never put loose in trash bags
Don't flush down the toilet

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Never place in trash or recycling
Small camping canisters: check for local hazardous waste collection
Large tanks: return to a propane dealer for refill or exchange
notes: Pressurized containers are a fire and explosion risk in garbage trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Don't put in curbside bins

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup with your municipality
Take to a mattress recycling facility
Some retailers offer take-back when delivering a new mattress
notes: Mattresses are recyclable — steel springs, foam, and fabric can all be recovered
commonMistakes: Don't leave on the curb without scheduling pickup
Don't put in dumpsters without permission

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing materials
instructions: Bubble wrap and air pillows: deflate and trash (or drop off with plastic bags at grocery stores)
Packing peanuts: return to shipping stores like UPS
Don't place in curbside recycling
notes: Plastic film clogs recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling
Don't let packing peanuts blow into the environment

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Contains mercury — handle with care
Take to a hazardous waste facility or participating retailer
Home Depot and Lowe's accept fluorescent tubes
notes: If a tube breaks, ventilate the area and clean up carefully
commonMistakes: Don't put in regular trash
Don't break them

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable due to wax or silicone coating
notes: Uncoated parchment paper may be compostable — check locally
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't confuse with regular paper

materials.name: Book
instructions: Donate if in good condition — libraries, thrift stores, and Little Free Libraries accept books
If damaged or unusable, remove the cover from hardcovers (trash the cover if it has a glossy laminate)
Recycle the paper pages in your recycling bin
notes: Books are made of paper and are recyclable, but donating is always the better option
Hardcover bindings with glue and fabric may need to be removed before recycling the pages
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in the trash — donate them first
Glossy laminated covers on hardcovers are not recyclable

materials.name: Magazine
instructions: Place directly in recycling bin
No need to remove staples or subscription cards
Glossy coating is fine — modern recycling handles it
notes: Magazines and catalogs are accepted in virtually all curbside programs
commonMistakes: Don't remove the staples — recycling equipment handles them
Magazines with heavy plastic wrapping: remove the plastic wrap first (trash it)

materials.name: Envelopes and mail
instructions: Regular paper envelopes: place in recycling
Window envelopes: recycle as-is — the small plastic window is OK
Padded/bubble mailers: trash (mixed materials)
notes: The small plastic window in envelopes is fine in modern recycling
commonMistakes: Don't worry about removing the plastic window
Padded bubble mailers cannot be recycled curbside

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Plain paper wrapping (no glitter, foil, or lamination): recycle
Metallic, glittery, or laminated wrapping paper: trash
Do the scrunch test — if it stays scrunched, it's paper (recycle). If it springs back, it's metallic (trash)
Tissue paper: compost or trash (fibers too short to recycle)
notes: Most wrapping paper has foil or glitter and goes in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't assume all wrapping paper is recyclable
Remove tape and bows before recycling plain paper wrap

materials.name: Receipt
instructions: Place in trash — do NOT recycle
Most receipts are thermal paper coated with BPA or BPS
If the receipt is clearly plain paper (not shiny/smooth), it can be recycled
notes: Thermal paper contaminates recycling batches with BPA chemicals
The shiny, smooth feel means it's thermal paper
commonMistakes: Don't put thermal receipts in recycling — they contaminate the paper stream
Don't compost thermal receipts either — the chemicals persist

materials.name: Sticky notes
instructions: Place in recycling bin
The small adhesive strip is fine — modern recycling handles it
notes: The adhesive on sticky notes is water-soluble and doesn't affect recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw away sticky notes thinking the glue contaminates recycling

materials.name: Greeting card
instructions: Plain paper/cardstock cards: recycle
Cards with glitter, foil, metallic finish, or batteries (musical cards): trash
Remove any plastic embellishments before recycling
notes: Musical greeting cards contain batteries — remove the battery and dispose of it as hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cards with glitter — it contaminates the recycling stream
Musical cards have small batteries inside that need separate disposal

materials.name: Candy wrapper
instructions: Place in trash
Candy wrappers are made of mixed metallized plastic film that cannot be recycled
Shake out any crumbs first
notes: Candy wrappers look like foil but are actually multi-layer plastic with a thin metal coating
They are too small and made of mixed materials for recycling equipment to process
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — they look metallic but are not aluminum
Don't put in compost — they don't break down

materials.name: Chip bag
instructions: Place in trash
Chip bags are metallized plastic film — not recyclable curbside
Empty all crumbs and food residue first
notes: The shiny interior of chip bags is a thin layer of aluminum bonded to plastic — it cannot be separated for recycling
Some specialty programs (like Terracycle) accept snack bags
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — the metallic interior makes them non-recyclable
Don't confuse with aluminum foil — they are different materials

materials.name: Granola bar wrapper
instructions: Place in trash
These are multi-layer flexible plastic that cannot be recycled curbside
notes: Like candy wrappers and chip bags, granola bar wrappers are mixed-material flexible packaging
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Fast food wrapper
instructions: Place in trash
Food-soiled paper is not recyclable
Wax-coated or grease-soaked wrappers cannot be composted in most programs
notes: Fast food wrappers are typically wax-coated and food-contaminated, making them non-recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy food wrappers in recycling — they contaminate clean paper

materials.name: Plastic clamshell container
instructions: Rinse off food residue
Place in recycling bin — most are #1 PET plastic
Keep the lid attached or recycle separately
notes: Clear plastic clamshells (like berry containers) are widely recyclable
Check for the recycling number — #1 and #5 are most accepted
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if heavily contaminated with food
Black plastic clamshells are often NOT recyclable (optical sorters can't detect them)

materials.name: Egg carton
instructions: Paper/cardboard egg cartons: recycle or compost
Styrofoam egg cartons: trash (not recyclable)
Plastic egg cartons: recycle if #1 PET
notes: Paper egg cartons are also great for composting — tear them up first
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam egg cartons in recycling
Check the material — the disposal method depends on whether it's paper, styrofoam, or plastic

materials.name: Cereal box
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove and trash the inner plastic bag/liner
Place flattened box in recycling bin
notes: Cereal boxes are thin paperboard (not corrugated cardboard) and are widely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove the plastic liner bag inside — that goes in the trash
Don't include boxes with heavy food contamination

materials.name: Frozen food box
instructions: Most frozen food boxes are coated with a moisture barrier (plastic or wax) and should go in the trash
Some programs now accept them — check locally
Ice cream cartons: usually trash due to plastic lining
notes: The coating that prevents frozen food boxes from getting soggy also makes them hard to recycle
commonMistakes: Don't assume frozen food boxes recycle like regular cardboard — the coating is different

materials.name: Snack pouch / drink pouch
instructions: Place in trash
Pouches are multi-layer mixed materials (plastic + aluminum + adhesive) that cannot be recycled curbside
Some brands offer mail-back recycling programs (Terracycle)
notes: Pouches are one of the fastest-growing packaging types and one of the hardest to recycle
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling
Don't confuse with juice boxes/cartons — cartons are recyclable, pouches are not

materials.name: Coffee pod / K-Cup
instructions: Most coffee pods go in the trash due to mixed materials (plastic + foil + coffee grounds)
Nespresso offers a free mail-back recycling program for their aluminum pods
Some K-Cup brands are now made with recyclable #5 plastic — peel the foil, empty the grounds, recycle the cup
notes: Check if your pod brand has a take-back program before trashing
commonMistakes: Don't put whole pods in recycling — the foil lid and coffee grounds contaminate
Nespresso aluminum pods should be mailed back, not put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Plastic cups
instructions: Rinse out any liquid
Place in recycling bin
Most rigid plastic cups are #1 PET or #5 PP and are recyclable
notes: Red Solo cups are #6 polystyrene — NOT recyclable in most programs
Clear plastic iced coffee cups (Starbucks, Dunkin) are usually #1 PET and ARE recyclable
commonMistakes: Red Solo cups are NOT recyclable despite being rigid plastic
Don't include cups with straws still in them

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in trash
Toothbrushes are mixed plastic and nylon bristles — not curbside recyclable
Some brands (like Preserve) offer mail-back recycling
notes: Consider switching to a bamboo toothbrush for a more sustainable option
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Toothpaste tube
instructions: Place in trash
Toothpaste tubes are multi-layer plastic with residue that makes them non-recyclable
Squeeze out as much product as possible first
notes: Some newer tubes (like Tom's of Maine) are now made with recyclable #2 HDPE — check the label
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling unless the tube specifically says recyclable

materials.name: Deodorant container
instructions: Place in trash
Deodorant containers are mixed materials (different plastics + a twist mechanism) that are hard to recycle
Some brands offer take-back programs
notes: The mix of plastic types and the internal mechanism make these non-recyclable in most programs
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — the mixed plastics contaminate the stream

materials.name: Razor
instructions: Wrap the blade carefully in tape or thick paper for safety
Place in trash
Never put loose blades in recycling — they injure sanitation workers
notes: Terracycle and Gillette offer mail-back recycling programs for razors
Safety razor metal blades can go in a blade bank and then to metal recycling
commonMistakes: Never put loose blades in recycling or trash without wrapping them
Don't flush razor blades

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics
instructions: Most makeup containers go in trash due to mixed materials, mirrors, and residue
Clean empty plastic containers (#1, #2, #5) can sometimes be recycled
Many brands (MAC, Kiehl's, Lush) have take-back recycling programs
notes: Check if your brand offers a container return program — many give discounts for returns
commonMistakes: Don't put small makeup containers in recycling — they fall through sorting screens
Remove mirrors from compacts before recycling the plastic

materials.name: Cleaning product bottle
instructions: Empty the bottle completely
Rinse briefly
Leave the trigger spray top on (or remove and trash it — varies by program)
Place in recycling bin
notes: Most cleaning bottles are #1 or #2 plastic and are widely recyclable
You don't need to remove every trace of product — a quick rinse is fine
commonMistakes: Don't recycle bottles that still have product in them
Trigger sprayers may not be accepted — check locally

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Wire hangers: return to dry cleaners (they reuse them) or take to scrap metal
Plastic hangers: trash (not curbside recyclable due to shape and material)
Wooden hangers: donate or trash
notes: Hangers jam recycling machinery due to their shape — never put them in curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Never put any type of hanger in curbside recycling
Wire hangers tangle in recycling equipment and cause shutdowns

materials.name: Broken ceramics / dishes
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cloth to prevent injury
Place in trash
Not recyclable in curbside glass recycling — ceramics contaminate glass
notes: Ceramics melt at a different temperature than glass and ruin glass recycling batches
Donate intact dishes to thrift stores instead of trashing them
commonMistakes: Never put ceramics in glass recycling — it ruins the entire batch
Don't put broken dishes in recycling unwrapped

materials.name: Mirror
instructions: Wrap in cardboard or thick cloth for safety
Label as 'BROKEN GLASS' if applicable
Place in trash — not recyclable
notes: Mirrors have a metallic coating that prevents them from being recycled with regular glass
commonMistakes: Never put mirrors in glass recycling — the coating contaminates it

materials.name: CDs / DVDs
instructions: Place in trash
CDs/DVDs are polycarbonate plastic — not recyclable curbside
Jewel cases can sometimes be recycled as #6 plastic (check locally)
Donate working discs to thrift stores or libraries
notes: Some e-waste centers accept CDs/DVDs for specialized recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Ink / toner cartridges
instructions: Return to office supply stores (Staples, Office Depot) — most offer free recycling
Many manufacturers (HP, Canon, Epson) have free mail-back programs
Do NOT put in trash or curbside recycling
notes: Ink cartridges contain residual ink and plastics that need specialized recycling
Some stores give rewards credit for returning cartridges
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash — the ink is a chemical waste
Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Pens and markers
instructions: Place in trash
Pens and markers are mixed materials (plastic body + ink + metal tip) and are not curbside recyclable
Crayola offers a ColorCycle program for used markers
notes: Too small and made of too many mixed materials for curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Tape
instructions: Place in trash
Tape is plastic film with adhesive — not recyclable
Small amounts of tape on cardboard boxes are OK to leave on for recycling
notes: You don't need to obsessively remove every piece of tape from recyclables — small amounts are fine
commonMistakes: Don't worry about small pieces of tape on cardboard — just remove large strips

materials.name: Candle
instructions: Wax and wick: place in trash
Glass candle jar: clean out the remaining wax (freeze it, then pop it out), then recycle the glass jar
Metal candle tins: clean and recycle as metal
notes: Wax is not recyclable or compostable in most programs
The glass jars are often reusable or recyclable once cleaned
commonMistakes: Don't put wax in recycling
Don't pour hot wax down the drain

materials.name: Rubber bands
instructions: Place in trash
Rubber is not recyclable in curbside programs
Reuse them when possible — they last a long time
notes: Rubber bands in recycling can tangle in sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Factory reset and delete all personal data first
Trade in at carrier stores (Verizon, T-Mobile, AT&T) or Apple/Samsung for credit
Donate working phones to charities
Take to e-waste recycling (Best Buy, Staples)
notes: Phones contain valuable metals (gold, silver, copper) worth recovering
It's illegal to put phones in the trash in many states
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash — phones contain lithium batteries and toxic metals
Don't forget to wipe personal data before recycling or donating

materials.name: Laptop / computer
instructions: Back up data, then factory reset / wipe the hard drive
Trade in at manufacturer (Apple, Dell, HP) for credit
Take to Best Buy or Staples for free e-waste recycling
Donate working computers to schools or nonprofits
notes: Computers contain valuable materials and hazardous components that need proper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash — it's illegal in many states and wastes valuable materials
Don't forget to remove/wipe personal data

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to e-waste recycling (Best Buy accepts cables for free)
Bundle cables neatly before dropping off
Do NOT put in curbside recycling — cables tangle in machinery
notes: Cables contain copper and other recoverable metals
commonMistakes: Never put cables or cords in curbside recycling — they wrap around sorting equipment
Don't throw in trash if you can avoid it — the copper is worth recycling

materials.name: Headphones / earbuds
instructions: Take to e-waste recycling
Best Buy accepts small electronics for free recycling
Wireless earbuds contain lithium batteries — do not put in trash
notes: Wired headphones tangle in recycling machinery
Wireless earbuds/headphones contain lithium batteries
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling or trash
Wireless earbuds are a fire risk in garbage trucks due to batteries

materials.name: Paper bag
instructions: Place in recycling bin
Can also be reused many times before recycling
Paper bags are also great for collecting other recyclables or compostables
notes: Paper bags are one of the most easily recyclable items
commonMistakes: Don't recycle paper bags that are heavily soiled with food or grease

materials.name: Plastic takeout container
instructions: Rinse out all food residue
Check the recycling number — #1, #2, and #5 are most accepted
Place clean container in recycling bin
notes: Black plastic takeout containers are often NOT recyclable (optical sorters can't see them)
commonMistakes: Don't recycle containers still full of food
Black plastic containers usually go in trash

materials.name: Styrofoam takeout container
instructions: Place in trash
Styrofoam food containers are not recyclable in most curbside programs
They are also food-contaminated, making them even harder to recycle
notes: Some cities are banning styrofoam food containers
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — styrofoam contaminates the stream

materials.name: Aluminum foil takeout container
instructions: Remove as much food residue as possible
Give it a quick rinse
Crumple slightly so it doesn't blow away
Place in recycling bin
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable and very valuable
A little residue is OK — it doesn't need to be spotless
commonMistakes: Don't trash aluminum containers just because they had food in them — a rinse is enough

materials.name: Paper plate
instructions: Clean paper plates with no plastic coating: compost
Food-soiled paper plates: compost (if available) or trash
Plastic-coated or wax-coated paper plates: trash
notes: Plain paper plates break down well in composting
If no composting is available, trash them — they are too food-soiled to recycle
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper plates in recycling

materials.name: Straw
instructions: Plastic straws: trash (too small for recycling equipment)
Paper straws: compost or trash
Metal/silicone reusable straws: wash and reuse
notes: Straws are too small for recycling sorting equipment — they fall through the screens
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic straws in recycling — they jam equipment

materials.name: Plastic utensils
instructions: Place in trash
Plastic utensils are too small and contaminated for curbside recycling
Consider carrying reusable utensils instead
notes: Even though they are plastic, their small size means they fall through recycling screens
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — they are too small to be sorted

materials.name: Bottle caps
instructions: Leave plastic caps ON plastic bottles — recycle together
Metal bottle caps: collect in a steel can, crimp it shut, then recycle the can
Loose caps fall through sorting screens — always attach them to something
notes: The old advice to remove caps is outdated — most programs now want caps left on
commonMistakes: Don't toss loose caps in recycling — they fall through screens and get lost
Leave caps on their bottles

materials.name: Prescription bottle
instructions: Remove the label (it contains personal health info)
Rinse out any residue
The bottle is #5 PP plastic — recyclable in most programs
Remove and trash the cap if it's a child-proof cap (mixed materials)
notes: Some pharmacies accept empty bottles for reuse
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove the label with your personal information
Don't put unused medications in with the bottle — dispose of meds separately

materials.name: Shoes
instructions: Wearable shoes: donate to thrift stores (Goodwill, Salvation Army)
Athletic shoes: Nike and many brands have take-back recycling programs
Worn-out shoes: place in textile recycling bins
Last resort: trash
notes: Shoes are one of the most commonly donated items — most thrift stores accept them
commonMistakes: Don't put shoes in curbside recycling
Tie pairs together so they don't get separated at donation centers

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag it and place in trash
Do NOT compost pet waste — it contains harmful bacteria
Cat litter (clay-based): trash
Cat litter (biodegradable): some can be composted — check the label
notes: Pet waste can contain parasites and pathogens that survive composting
commonMistakes: Never compost dog or cat waste
Don't flush cat litter — it can harm marine life
Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Flowers and plants
instructions: Remove from any plastic wrapping, foam, or wire
Place plant material in compost or yard waste bin
Ceramic or plastic pots: see ceramics or plastic entries
notes: All natural plant matter is compostable
Remove any non-organic materials first (ribbon, foam, wire)
commonMistakes: Don't compost the plastic pot — only the plant
Remove rubber bands, wire, and ribbons first

materials.name: Pizza (the food)
instructions: The pizza itself (food): compost if available, otherwise trash
Pizza box: recycle (tear off heavily greased parts)
These are two separate items — handle each correctly
notes: The food and the box have different disposal paths
commonMistakes: Don't put the pizza food in recycling
The pizza box is a separate item — see pizza box entry

materials.name: Ice / ice cubes
instructions: Regular ice: just let it melt — it's water
Ice packs (gel): trash the gel pack, don't pour gel down drain
Dry ice: let it sublimate outdoors in a ventilated area — never trash or pour water on it
notes: Regular ice is literally just water — no disposal needed
Gel ice packs are NOT just water — the gel is trash
commonMistakes: Don't pour gel ice pack contents down the drain
Don't handle dry ice with bare hands

materials.name: Tissues and toilet paper
instructions: Used tissues and toilet paper: trash
The cardboard toilet paper roll: recycle
Never put used tissues in recycling
notes: Used tissues may carry germs — trash is the safest option
The empty cardboard tube IS recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put used tissues in recycling
Do recycle the empty cardboard tube

materials.name: Cardboard tubes
instructions: Place in recycling bin
Flatten if possible
notes: These are clean cardboard and are easily recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't throw these away — they're perfectly recyclable

materials.name: Sponge
instructions: Place in trash
Sponges are mixed materials and not recyclable
Replace kitchen sponges regularly for hygiene
notes: Some natural sea sponges are compostable, but synthetic sponges are trash
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't compost synthetic sponges

materials.name: Aluminum pie pan / food tray
instructions: Rinse off food residue
Crumple slightly
Place in recycling bin
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable — even food trays
commonMistakes: Don't trash aluminum trays — they're valuable recyclables
A quick rinse is all that's needed

materials.name: Drinking glass / Pyrex
instructions: Wrap carefully and place in trash
Drinking glasses and Pyrex are NOT the same as bottle glass — they melt at different temperatures
Label as 'BROKEN GLASS' if broken
notes: Drinking glasses, Pyrex, and crystal have different chemical compositions than bottle glass
commonMistakes: Never put drinking glasses or Pyrex in glass recycling — they ruin the batch

materials.name: Tupperware / food storage containers
instructions: If still usable: keep using it or donate
If broken/stained: check recycling number (#1, #2, #5 are recyclable)
Remove the lid — lids and containers may be different plastics
notes: Reusing is always better than recycling for durable containers
commonMistakes: Don't throw away usable containers — donate them
Check the recycling number before putting in the bin

materials.name: Ziploc / resealable bags
instructions: Place in trash — not curbside recyclable
Many grocery stores accept clean plastic bags/film at drop-off bins
Reuse them when possible before trashing
notes: Same rules as plastic bags — they jam recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling
Reuse before trashing when possible

materials.name: Cling wrap / plastic wrap
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable due to food contamination and thin film
Consider switching to beeswax wraps or silicone lids
notes: Plastic wrap is too thin and contaminated for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't put in compost — it's plastic

materials.name: School / office supplies
instructions: Paper notebooks: remove spiral wire (recycle wire as metal), recycle paper
Binders: disassemble — recycle the cardboard, trash the plastic and metal rings
Pencils: trash (too small)
Erasers: trash
Index cards: recycle if clean
notes: Most school paper products are recyclable
Plastic components need to be separated
commonMistakes: Don't recycle a spiral notebook with the metal spiral still in — remove it first
Plastic folders/binders go in trash

materials.name: Toys
instructions: Working toys in good condition: donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or children's charities
Broken plastic toys: trash (mixed materials)
Board games with all pieces: donate
Electronic toys: remove batteries first, then donate or e-waste recycle
notes: Donation is the best option for working toys
Toys are mixed materials and not curbside recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put toys in curbside recycling
Remove batteries from electronic toys before disposal

materials.name: Sports equipment
instructions: Working equipment: donate to schools, youth programs, or thrift stores
Deflated balls: trash
Yoga mats: trash (mixed materials)
Metal equipment (dumbbells): scrap metal recycling
notes: Play It Again Sports buys and sells used sports equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling
Donate before trashing if still usable

materials.name: Keys
instructions: Metal keys: collect several and recycle as scrap metal
Key fobs with batteries: remove battery (hazardous waste), trash the fob
Single keys are too small for curbside — save up a handful and take to scrap metal
notes: Keys are typically brass or steel and are recyclable as metal
commonMistakes: Single loose keys fall through recycling screens — batch them together

materials.name: Sunglasses / eyeglasses
instructions: Working glasses: donate to Lions Club, LensCrafters, or Goodwill
Broken glasses: trash
Many optometrists have donation boxes in their offices
notes: Lions Club International collects and distributes glasses worldwide
commonMistakes: Don't throw away usable glasses — donate them

materials.name: Umbrella
instructions: Place in trash
Umbrellas are mixed materials (metal, plastic, fabric) and not recyclable
If the metal frame is separable, that part can go to scrap metal
notes: The mix of materials makes umbrellas non-recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Backpack / bag
instructions: Good condition: donate to thrift stores or shelters
Worn out: place in textile recycling bins
Last resort: trash
notes: Backpacks and bags are often accepted by homeless shelters
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling
Empty all pockets before donating

recycle: Paper, newspapers, magazines, books, mail, envelopes
Clean aluminum foil and foil trays
compost: Food scraps (fruit, vegetables, coffee grounds, eggshells)
Paper towels, napkins, and plain paper plates
trash: Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

recycle: Plastic bags, film, and flexible wrappers
Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches
compost: Meat and dairy (in most municipal programs)

tips: When in doubt, throw it out — contamination hurts recycling
Rinse containers but they don't need to be spotless
Check your local municipality's specific rules
Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Flatten cardboard and cereal boxes to save space
Keep recyclables loose in the bin
Leave bottle caps ON their bottles — don't toss them loose
Books in good condition? Donate before recycling
Candy wrappers look metallic but are NOT aluminum — they go in trash
